The **UCLA Bruins men 's basketball** program represents the [University of
California, Los Angeles](/wiki/University_of_California,_Los_Angeles
"University of California, Los Angeles") (UCLA) in men's [college
basketball](/wiki/College_basketball "College basketball"). Established in
1919, the program has won a record 11 [NCAA
titles](/wiki/NCAA_Division_I_Men%27s_Basketball_Championship "NCAA Division I
Men's Basketball Championship"), which is also tied with the [Connecticut
Huskies women's team](/wiki/Connecticut_Huskies_women%27s_basketball
"Connecticut Huskies women's basketball") for the most in all of college
basketball. UCLA teams coached by [John Wooden](/wiki/John_Wooden "John
Wooden") won 10 national titles in 12 seasons, from 1964 to 1975, including
seven straight from 1967 to 1973. UCLA went undefeated a record four times, in
1964, 1967, 1972, and 1973. Coach [Jim Harrick](/wiki/Jim_Harrick "Jim
Harrick") led the team to another NCAA title in 1995. Former coach [Ben
Howland](/wiki/Ben_Howland "Ben Howland") led UCLA to three consecutive [Final
Four](/wiki/Final_Four "Final Four") appearances from 2006 to 2008.[2] As a
member of the AAWU, Pacific-8 and then Pacific-10, UCLA set a NCAA Division I
record with 13 consecutive regular season conference titles between 1967 and
1979 which stood until passed by
[Kansas](/wiki/Kansas_Jayhawks_men%27s_basketball "Kansas Jayhawks men's
basketball") in 2018.[3] On March 30, 2013, [Steve Alford](/wiki/Steve_Alford
"Steve Alford") was named the school's 13th head men's basketball coach.[4]

## NCAA
records[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: NCAA records")]

UCLA men's basketball has set several NCAA records.[5][6][7]

  * 11 NCAA titles
  * 7 consecutive NCAA titles (1967–1973)
  * 12 NCAA title game appearances*
  * 10 consecutive Final Four appearances (1967–1976)
  * 25 Final Four wins*
  * 38 game NCAA Tournament winning streak (1964–1974)
  * 134 weeks ranked No. 1 in AP Top 25 Poll
  * 221 consecutive weeks ranked in AP Top 25 Poll (1966–1980)
  * 54 consecutive winning seasons (1949–2002)
  * 88 game men's regular season [winning streak](/wiki/Basketball_winning_streaks "Basketball winning streaks") (1971–1974)
  * 13 consecutive Div-I regular season conference titles (1966–1979)**
  * 4 undefeated seasons (1964, 1967, 1972, 1973)

* Excludes 1980 tournament results vacated by NCAA

** Surpassed by [Kansas](/wiki/Kansas_Jayhawks_men%27s_basketball "Kansas
Jayhawks men's basketball") in 2018

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: History")]

### Early UCLA
basketball[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Early UCLA basketball")]

In 1919, [Fred Cozens](/wiki/Fred_Cozens "Fred Cozens") became the first head
coach of the UCLA basketball and football teams. Cozens coached the basketball
team for two seasons, finishing with an overall record of 21–4. [Caddy
Works](/wiki/Caddy_Works "Caddy Works") was the head coach of the Bruins from
1921 to 1939, guiding them to a 173-159 record. Works was a lawyer by
profession and coached the team only during the evenings. According to UCLA
player and future Olympian [Frank Lubin](/wiki/Frank_Lubin "Frank Lubin"),
Works was "more of an honorary coach" with little basketball knowledge.[8]
[Wilbur Johns](/wiki/Wilbur_Johns "Wilbur Johns") was the UCLA basketball head
coach from 1939 to 1948, guiding the Bruins to a 93-120 record.

### The John Wooden
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: The John Wooden era")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/John_Wooden.JPG/220px-
John_Wooden.JPG)](/wiki/File:John_Wooden.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:John_Wooden.JPG "Enlarge")

[John Wooden](/wiki/John_Wooden "John Wooden") coached UCLA to 10 national
championships

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Lew_Alcindor_Kareem_Abdul-
Jabbar_UCLA.jpg/220px-Lew_Alcindor_Kareem_Abdul-
Jabbar_UCLA.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lew_Alcindor_Kareem_Abdul-Jabbar_UCLA.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lew_Alcindor_Kareem_Abdul-Jabbar_UCLA.jpg "Enlarge")

Lew Alcindor ([Kareem Abdul-Jabbar](/wiki/Kareem_Abdul-Jabbar "Kareem Abdul-
Jabbar")) makes a reverse two hand [dunk](/wiki/Slam_dunk "Slam dunk")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Bill_Walton_1974_cropped.JPG/220px-
Bill_Walton_1974_cropped.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bill_Walton_1974_cropped.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Bill_Walton_1974_cropped.JPG "Enlarge")

[Bill Walton](/wiki/Bill_Walton "Bill Walton") taking a shot

From 1948 to 1975, [John Wooden](/wiki/John_Wooden "John Wooden"), nicknamed
the "Wizard of [Westwood](/wiki/Westwood,_Los_Angeles "Westwood, Los
Angeles")", served as UCLA's head coach. He won ten
[NCAA](/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association "National Collegiate
Athletic Association") national championships in a 12-year period, including a
run of seven in a row that shattered the previous record of only two
consecutive titles.[9][10] Within this period, his teams won a men's
basketball-record 88 consecutive games.

Prior to Wooden's arrival, UCLA had only won two conference championships in
the previous 18 years. In his first season, Wooden guided a UCLA team that had
finished with a 12–13 record the previous year to a 22–7 record—then the most
wins in a season in program history—and the [Pacific Coast
Conference](/wiki/Pacific_Coast_Conference "Pacific Coast Conference") (PCC)
Southern Division championship.[10][11] In his second season, Wooden led the
Bruins to a 24–7 record and the PCC championship. The Bruins would win the
division title in each of the next two seasons and the conference title in the
latter season. Up to that time, UCLA had won only two division titles since
the PCC began divisional play, and it had not won a conference title of any
kind since winning the [Southern California Intercollegiate Athletic
Conference](/wiki/Southern_California_Intercollegiate_Athletic_Conference
"Southern California Intercollegiate Athletic Conference") in 1927.

In 1955–56, Wooden guided the Bruins to their first undefeated PCC conference
title and a 17-game winning streak that only came to an end in the 1956 NCAA
Tournament at the hands of a [University of San
Francisco](/wiki/University_of_San_Francisco "University of San Francisco")
team that featured [Bill Russell](/wiki/Bill_Russell "Bill Russell"). However,
UCLA was unable to maintain this level of performance over the immediate
ensuing seasons, finding itself unable to return to the NCAA Tournament as the
[Pete Newell](/wiki/Pete_Newell "Pete Newell")-coached
[California](/wiki/California_Golden_Bears_men%27s_basketball "California
Golden Bears men's basketball") teams took control of the conference at the
end of the decade. Also hampering the fortunes of Wooden's team during that
time period was a probation imposed on all UCLA sports in the aftermath of a
[scandal](/wiki/Pacific_Coast_Conference#The_crisis "Pacific Coast
Conference") involving illegal payments made to players on the school's
football team, along with USC, Cal and Stanford, resulting in the dismantling
of the PCC conference.[12]

By 1962 the probation was no longer in place and Wooden had returned the
Bruins to the top of their conference (now the [Pac-12
Conference](/wiki/Pac-12_Conference "Pac-12 Conference")). This time, however,
they would take the next step, and go on to unleash a run of dominance
unparalleled in the history of college sports. A narrow loss due largely to a
controversial foul call in the semifinal of the 1962 NCAA Tournament convinced
Wooden that his Bruins were ready to contend for national championships.[12]
Two seasons later, the final piece of the puzzle fell into place when
assistant coach [Jerry Norman](/wiki/Jerry_Norman_\(basketball\) "Jerry Norman
\(basketball\)") persuaded Wooden that the team's small-sized players and
fast-paced offense would be complemented by the adoption of a zone press
defense.[12] The result was a dramatic increase in scoring, giving UCLA a
powerhouse team led by [Walt Hazzard](/wiki/Walt_Hazzard "Walt Hazzard") and
[Gail Goodrich](/wiki/Gail_Goodrich "Gail Goodrich") that went undefeated on
its way to the school's first basketball national championship.

Wooden's team repeated as national champions the following season before the
squad fell briefly in 1966 when it finished second in the conference to
[Oregon State](/wiki/Oregon_State "Oregon State"). UCLA was ineligible to play
in the NCAA tournament that year because in those days only conference
champions went to the tournament. However, the Bruins' incarnation returned
with a vengeance in 1967 with the arrival of sophomore All-America and MVP
[Lew Alcindor](/wiki/Lew_Alcindor "Lew Alcindor"). The team reclaimed not only
the conference title but the national crown with an undefeated season.

In January 1968, UCLA took its 47-game winning streak to the
[Astrodome](/wiki/Astrodome "Astrodome") in [Houston](/wiki/Houston
"Houston"), where Alcindor squared off against [Elvin Hayes](/wiki/Elvin_Hayes
"Elvin Hayes") in the [Game of the
Century](/wiki/Game_of_the_Century_\(college_basketball\) "Game of the Century
\(college basketball\)"), which was the nation's first nationally televised
regular season college basketball game. Houston upset UCLA 71-69 behind Hayes'
39 points. In a post-game interview, Wooden stated, "We have to start over."
They did, and went undefeated the rest of the year, avenging Houston 101-69 in
the semi-final rematch of the NCAA tournament en route to the national
championship. Hayes, who had been averaging 37.7 points per game, was held to
only 10 points. Wooden credited Norman for devising the diamond-and-one
defense that contained the Houston center.[13][14]

The emergence of the Bruins under Wooden vastly increased the program's
popularity. Since 1932, the Bruins had played at the [Men's
Gym](/wiki/Men%27s_Gym "Men's Gym"). It normally seated 2,400, but had been
limited to 1,500 since 1955 by order of the city fire marshal. This forced
games to be moved to [Pan Pacific Auditorium](/wiki/Pan_Pacific_Auditorium
"Pan Pacific Auditorium"), the [Los Angeles Memorial Sports
Arena](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Memorial_Sports_Arena "Los Angeles Memorial Sports
Arena") and other venues around Los Angeles when larger crowds were
expected—an increasing inconvenience since the Bruins' first national title.
At Wooden's urging, a much larger on-campus facility was built in time for the
1965–66 season, the nearly 13,000 seat [Pauley Pavilion](/wiki/Pauley_Pavilion
"Pauley Pavilion"), .

Wooden coached his final game in Pauley Pavilion on March 1, 1975, when UCLA
trounced [Stanford](/wiki/Stanford_Cardinal_men%27s_basketball "Stanford
Cardinal men's basketball") 93–59. Four weeks later, following a 75–74
overtime victory over
[Louisville](/wiki/Louisville_Cardinals_men%27s_basketball "Louisville
Cardinals men's basketball") in the 1975 NCAA Tournament semifinal game,
Wooden announced that he would retire at age 64 immediately after the
championship game.[15] His legendary coaching career concluded triumphantly,
as his team responded with a win over
[Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky_Wildcats_men%27s_basketball "Kentucky Wildcats men's
basketball") to claim Wooden's first career coaching victory over the Wildcats
and his unprecedented 10th national championship in a twelve-year span.

During his tenure with the Bruins, Wooden became known as the "Wizard of
[Westwood](/wiki/Westwood,_Los_Angeles "Westwood, Los Angeles")", although he
personally disdained the nickname. He gained lasting fame at UCLA by winning
620 games in 27 seasons and 10 NCAA titles during his last 12 seasons, which
included seven in a row from 1967 to 1973.[9] His UCLA teams also had a then-
record winning streak of 88 games[16][17] and four perfect 30–0 seasons.[9]
They also won 38 straight games in NCAA Tournaments[9] and 98 straight home
game wins at [Pauley Pavilion](/wiki/Pauley_Pavilion "Pauley Pavilion").
Wooden was named NCAA College Basketball's "Coach of the Year" in 1964, 1967,
1969, 1970, 1971, 1972 and 1973. In 1967, he was named the [Henry Iba
Award](/wiki/Henry_Iba_Award "Henry Iba Award") USBWA College Basketball Coach
of the Year. In 1972, he shared _[Sports Illustrated](/wiki/Sports_Illustrated
"Sports Illustrated")_ magazine's "[Sportsman of the
Year](/wiki/Sportsman_of_the_Year "Sportsman of the Year")" award with [Billie
Jean King](/wiki/Billie_Jean_King "Billie Jean King"). He was named to the
Basketball Hall of Fame as a coach in 1973,[18] becoming the first to be
honored as both a player and a coach.[10]

### Post-Wooden
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Post-Wooden era")]

From 1975 to 1977, [Gene Bartow](/wiki/Gene_Bartow "Gene Bartow") served as
the head coach of [UCLA](/wiki/University_of_California,_Los_Angeles
"University of California, Los Angeles"). He guided them to a 52–9 record,
including a berth in the 1976 [Final Four](/wiki/Final_Four "Final Four"). He
coached the 1977 College Player of the Year, [Marques
Johnson](/wiki/Marques_Johnson "Marques Johnson").

[Gary Cunningham](/wiki/Gary_Cunningham "Gary Cunningham") became the head
coach at UCLA in 1977. He coached two seasons, winning the Pacific-8 and
Pacific-10 conference championships and leading UCLA to a #2 ranking in the
final polls both seasons.

[Larry Brown](/wiki/Larry_Brown_\(basketball\) "Larry Brown \(basketball\)")
then moved on to coach UCLA from 1979–1981, leading his freshman-dominated
1979–80 team to the NCAA title game before falling to
[Louisville](/wiki/Louisville_Cardinals_men%27s_basketball "Louisville
Cardinals men's basketball"), 59–54. However, that runner-up finish was later
vacated by the NCAA after two players were found to be ineligible. This was
one of the few times a Final Four squad had its record vacated (Villanova had
its runner-up finish vacated in 1971 because [Howard
Porter](/wiki/Howard_Porter_\(basketball\) "Howard Porter \(basketball\)") had
signed a pro contract).[19]

[Larry Farmer](/wiki/Larry_Farmer_\(basketball\) "Larry Farmer
\(basketball\)") was the head coach of UCLA from 1981 to 1984, guiding them to
a 61–23 (.726) record. He had recruited [Earvin "Magic"
Johnson](/wiki/Magic_Johnson "Magic Johnson") to come play at UCLA, but then
told Johnson to hold off on a visit as he was more interested in [Albert
King](/wiki/Albert_King_\(basketball\) "Albert King \(basketball\)").[20]
Neither played for UCLA.

In 1984, [Walt Hazzard](/wiki/Walt_Hazzard "Walt Hazzard") was named the UCLA
basketball coach twenty years after winning the national championship as a
player. He coached for four seasons, winning 77 out of 125 games. The
1984–1985 UCLA Bruin basketball team won the
[NIT](/wiki/National_Invitation_Tournament "National Invitation Tournament")
championship. The 1986–1987 UCLA Bruin basketball team won both the
[Pac-10](/wiki/Pacific-10_Conference_men%27s_basketball "Pacific-10 Conference
men's basketball") regular season championship as well as the inaugural
[Pacific-10 Conference Men's Basketball
Tournament](/wiki/Pacific-10_Conference_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournament
"Pacific-10 Conference Men's Basketball Tournament").

### The Jim Harrick
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: The Jim Harrick era")]

In 1988, [Jim Harrick](/wiki/Jim_Harrick "Jim Harrick") returned to UCLA (he
had spent two years as an assistant coach from 1978 to 1979) to assume head
coaching duties after the firing of [Walt Hazzard](/wiki/Walt_Hazzard "Walt
Hazzard"). During the recruiting period before his first season, he recruited
[Don MacLean](/wiki/Don_MacLean_\(basketball\) "Don MacLean \(basketball\)"),
the most significant recruit to commit to UCLA in several years. McLean's
arrival helped start a revival of the basketball program. Within four years,
the Bruins were in the Elite Eight--"officially" their deepest advance in the
tournament in 13 years, and only the second time they had gone that far since
Wooden's departure.

During the [1994–1995
season](/wiki/1994%E2%80%9395_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_team "1994–95
UCLA Bruins men's basketball team"), he led UCLA to a 31-2 record (a loss to
California was subsequently forfeited to the Bruins) and the school's
[eleventh national
championship](/wiki/1995_NCAA_Division_I_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournament "1995
NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament"), its first since the [1974–75
season](/wiki/1974%E2%80%9375_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_team "1974–75
UCLA Bruins men's basketball team"). The 31 wins would stand as a school
record until the 2005–06 season. In 1996, Harrick's Bruins were upset in the
first round by [Princeton](/wiki/Princeton_Tigers "Princeton Tigers"). Shortly
before the 1996 season, UCLA fired Harrick for lying about who attended a
recruiting dinner. At the time, he was the second-winningest coach in school
history.

### The Steve Lavin
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: The Steve Lavin era")]

On the departure of assistants [Mark Gottfried](/wiki/Mark_Gottfried "Mark
Gottfried") and [Lorenzo Romar](/wiki/Lorenzo_Romar "Lorenzo Romar") for head
coaching jobs shortly after the 1995 NCAA Championship season, Lavin, as the
assistant with the longest tenure at UCLA, was selected as interim head coach.

Later that season on February 11, 1997, with the Bruins tied for first place
in the Pac-10 with an 8–3 record, UCLA removed the "interim" tag from Lavin's
title and formally named him as its 11th head coach. The Bruins then won their
next 11 games en route to the Pac-10 title, before being eliminated by the
[Minnesota Gophers](/wiki/Minnesota_Golden_Gophers_men%27s_basketball
"Minnesota Golden Gophers men's basketball") in the NCAA Midwest Regional
Final. In seven seasons as head coach Lavin's record was 12–4 in games
involving overtime. Additionally Lavin's Bruins had a 10–4 record against the
rival [USC Trojans](/wiki/USC_Trojans_men%27s_basketball "USC Trojans men's
basketball"). During the period 1997–2002, Lavin's Bruins compiled nine
consecutive overtime victories. These included victories over
[Arizona](/wiki/Arizona "Arizona"), [Cincinnati](/wiki/Cincinnati
"Cincinnati") (2002 NCAA second round double overtime victory over No. 1 West
Region seed), [Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky "Kentucky"), and
[Stanford](/wiki/Stanford "Stanford") (then ranked No 1). The Stanford win was
sealed by a last second jumper by star sophomore guard [JaRon
Rush](/wiki/JaRon_Rush "JaRon Rush").

At UCLA from 1996 to 2003, Lavin compiled a record of 145–78. As both an
assistant and head coach, Lavin participated in 13 consecutive NCAA tournament
appearances (1990–2002), while working at Purdue and UCLA. During Lavin's
tenure as a head coach, he was one of only two coaches in the country to lead
his team to five NCAA "Sweet 16s" in six years (1997, 1998, 2000–2002), the
other coach being [Duke's](/wiki/Duke_University "Duke University") [Mike
Krzyzewski](/wiki/Mike_Krzyzewski "Mike Krzyzewski"). Lavin guided UCLA to six
consecutive seasons of 20 or more wins, as well as six consecutive NCAA
tournament appearances.[21]

Lavin signed seven McDonald's High School All-Americans. Seven of Lavin's
former Bruin recruits became roster members of NBA teams: [Trevor
Ariza](/wiki/Trevor_Ariza "Trevor Ariza"), [Matt Barnes](/wiki/Matt_Barnes
"Matt Barnes"), [Baron Davis](/wiki/Baron_Davis "Baron Davis"), [Dan
Gadzuric](/wiki/Dan_Gadzuric "Dan Gadzuric"), [Ryan
Hollins](/wiki/Ryan_Hollins "Ryan Hollins"), [Jason Kapono](/wiki/Jason_Kapono
"Jason Kapono"), and [Earl Watson](/wiki/Earl_Watson "Earl Watson").

During Lavin's tenure as head coach, the Bruins qualified for six consecutive
NCAA Tournaments (1997–2002). Lavin's record in the first and second rounds of
the NCAA tournament is 10–1. His winning percentage (90.9%) in the first two
rounds is second only to Dean Smith in NCAA Tournament history. However, Lavin
also coached the Bruins to their only loss in an NCAA tournament game played
in the State of California (a 2002 loss to Missouri in San Jose).

In seven seasons as head coach Lavin's record was 12–4 in games involving
overtime. The Bruins defeated the No. 1 team in the country in four
consecutive collegiate seasons: Stanford in 2000 and 2001, Kansas in 2002 and
Arizona in 2003.

In March 2003, following UCLA's first losing season (10–19) in 55 years, Lavin
was fired.

Despite some success under the watch of Steve Lavin, the program wanted to
regain its position in the college basketball upper echelon. Even the success
in the NCAA tournament belied the fact that UCLA had earned no better than a
number 4 seed with the exception of the 1997 season. The
[2002–03](/wiki/2002%E2%80%9303_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_season
"2002–03 NCAA Division I men's basketball season") season turned out to be the
back-breaker for Lavin as the Bruins stumbled to a 10–19 record and a 6–12
record in the conference. It was the first losing season for UCLA in over five
decades. Lavin was dismissed following the season.

### Ben Howland era
(2003–2013)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Ben Howland era \(2003–2013\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Russell_Westbrook_guarding_OJ_Mayo_cropped.jpg/220px-
Russell_Westbrook_guarding_OJ_Mayo_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Russell_Westbrook_guarding_OJ_Mayo_cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Russell_Westbrook_guarding_OJ_Mayo_cropped.jpg "Enlarge")

[Russell Westbrook](/wiki/Russell_Westbrook "Russell Westbrook") (left) and
[Kevin Love](/wiki/Kevin_Love "Kevin Love") defend against
[USC](/wiki/USC_Trojans_men%27s_basketball "USC Trojans men's basketball")

UCLA looked to find a coach that could move the Bruins back to the elite ranks
of the Pac-10 and the country. Howland's success at the University of
Pittsburgh and his southern California roots made him an attractive candidate.
In 2003, he left Pitt and accepted the head coaching duties at UCLA.[22]

Howland remedied this disappointment in his recruiting efforts. Howland
produced a top tier recruiting class from athletes in southern California that
fit his Big East style. Behind Lavin hold-over Dijon Thompson and Howland
recruits [Jordan Farmar](/wiki/Jordan_Farmar "Jordan Farmar") and [Arron
Afflalo](/wiki/Arron_Afflalo "Arron Afflalo"), UCLA produced a winning season
for the first time in three years and returned to the tournament, where they
lost in the first round.

Starting the [2005–06
season](/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_season
"2005–06 NCAA Division I men's basketball season") with the majority of the
roster made over in Howland's image and with the Lavin hold-overs (e.g., [Ryan
Hollins](/wiki/Ryan_Hollins "Ryan Hollins") and [Cedric
Bozeman](/wiki/Cedric_Bozeman "Cedric Bozeman")), the Bruins produced an
excellent campaign. They finished the regular season 24–6, winning the Pac-10
Conference title. They then roared through the [Pac-10
tournament](/wiki/2006_Pacific-10_Conference_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournament
"2006 Pacific-10 Conference Men's Basketball Tournament"), winning each game
by double digits en route to only the second Pac-10 tournament championship in
school history. The momentum continued into the NCAA tournament as the second-
seeded Bruins defeated [Gonzaga](/wiki/Gonzaga_Bulldogs_men%27s_basketball
"Gonzaga Bulldogs men's basketball") in the Sweet Sixteen. They then upset
top-seeded Memphis to reach the school's first Final Four in 11 years. The run
ended in the championship game against
[Florida](/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_Florida_Gators_men%27s_basketball_team
"2005–06 Florida Gators men's basketball team"), whose imposing front-line
proved to be a matchup problem for the Bruins.

Howland continued his success at UCLA the following year. The
[Bruins](/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_team "2006–07
UCLA Bruins men's basketball team") finished undefeated at home for the first
time in 22 years, winning the Pac-10 conference title. However they lost in
their first [Pac-10 tournament
game](/wiki/2007_Pacific-10_Conference_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournament "2007
Pacific-10 Conference Men's Basketball Tournament") and were seeded second in
the NCAA Tournament West Region. After a close second-round win over
[Indiana](/wiki/Indiana_Hoosiers_men%27s_basketball "Indiana Hoosiers men's
basketball"), Howland led the Bruins to a win over his former team,
[Pitt](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Panthers_men%27s_basketball "Pittsburgh Panthers men's
basketball") in the Sweet Sixteen. The Bruins then again upset the top seed in
the West Region,
[Kansas](/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_Kansas_Jayhawks_men%27s_basketball_team
"2006–07 Kansas Jayhawks men's basketball team"), and reached the second of
UCLA's first consecutive Final Fours since the [John Wooden](/wiki/John_Wooden
"John Wooden") era, only to lose again to
[Florida](/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_Florida_Gators_men%27s_basketball_team
"2006–07 Florida Gators men's basketball team") in the national semifinal.

At the start of the [2007–08
season](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_season
"2007–08 NCAA Division I men's basketball season"), expectations for
[UCLA](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_team "2007–08 UCLA
Bruins men's basketball team") were the highest ever with the arrival of
[Kevin Love](/wiki/Kevin_Love "Kevin Love"), one of the best low-post
prospects in the high school class of 2007.[23] Combined with the emergence of
[Russell Westbrook](/wiki/Russell_Westbrook "Russell Westbrook") and [Darren
Collison](/wiki/Darren_Collison "Darren Collison") in the back-court, the
Bruins won their 3rd consecutive Pac-10 conference title, and their second
[Pac-10 tournament
title](/wiki/2008_Pacific-10_Conference_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournament "2008
Pacific-10 Conference Men's Basketball Tournament") in three years. They
received their first #1 seed in the NCAA tournament since 1995, and once again
reached the Final Four, where they faced another top seed, the [Memphis
Tigers](/wiki/Memphis_Tigers_men%27s_basketball "Memphis Tigers men's
basketball"). Memphis got the better of the Bruins, who returned to Westwood
without a championship once again.

However, the Bruins program under Howland began to struggle in subsequent
seasons. After 2008, UCLA did not advance past the first weekend of the NCAA
tourney, and did not qualify for the tournament in
[2010](/wiki/2009%E2%80%9310_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_team "2009–10 UCLA
Bruins men's basketball team") and
[2012](/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_team "2011–12 UCLA
Bruins men's basketball team").[24] With a 77-73 victory over
[Penn](/wiki/Penn_Quakers_men%27s_basketball "Penn Quakers men's basketball")
on December 10, 2011; Howland passed [Jim Harrick](/wiki/Jim_Harrick "Jim
Harrick") for second on UCLA's all-time wins list behind [John
Wooden](/wiki/John_Wooden "John Wooden"). Nonetheless, questions about how
Howland was running the program began to come into focus. In February 2012, a
_[Sports Illustrated](/wiki/Sports_Illustrated "Sports Illustrated")_ article
portrayed UCLA player [Reeves Nelson](/wiki/Reeves_Nelson "Reeves Nelson") as
a bully on and off the court, who at times intentionally tried to injure his
teammates. According to the article, Howland looked the other way and did not
discipline Nelson for over two years.[25][26] From 2008—the Bruins last Final
Four appearance—through 2012, at least 11 players left the UCLA program.[27]

Although the 2012–2013 Bruins won the Pac-12 regular season championship, they
quickly bowed out in the first round of the NCAA tournament. On March 25,
2013, three days after being eliminated by 11th seed Minnesota, UCLA fired
Howland.[28][29]

### Steve Alford era
(2013–present)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Steve Alford era \(2013–present\)")]

On March 30, 2013, Alford signed a seven-year, $18.2-million contract to
become the head coach of UCLA, replacing the fired [Ben
Howland](/wiki/Ben_Howland "Ben Howland").[30] In his first year as head coach
Alford led UCLA to a Pac-12 tournament championship, a feat not accomplished
since 2008. The team later went on to the "Sweet Sixteen" of the [NCAA
Division I Men's Basketball
Tournament](/wiki/NCAA_Division_I_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournament "NCAA Division
I Men's Basketball Tournament") as a 4 seed in the South regional before
losing to the 1 seed Florida.

In his second year, the team was controversially chosen to participate in the
[2015 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball
Tournament](/wiki/2015_NCAA_Division_I_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournament "2015
NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament") as an 11 seed in the South
Region, where they upset the 6 seed
[SMU](/wiki/Southern_Methodist_Mustangs_men%27s_basketball "Southern Methodist
Mustangs men's basketball") on a game-winning goaltending call. The Bruins
went on to defeat the [University of Alabama at Birmingham
Blazers](/wiki/UAB_Blazers_men%27s_basketball "UAB Blazers men's basketball")
before losing to rival [Gonzaga](/wiki/Gonzaga_Bulldogs_men%27s_basketball
"Gonzaga Bulldogs men's basketball") in the "Sweet Sixteen."

After a disappointing third season in which UCLA suffered their fourth losing
record since 1948, the team rebounded in the following season, going 31-5
before falling to [Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky_Wildcats_men%27s_basketball
"Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball"), once again in the "Sweet Sixteen."
Freshman point guard [Lonzo Ball](/wiki/Lonzo_Ball "Lonzo Ball"), as well as
the program in general, garnered national media attention for the outspoken
behavior of his father [LaVar Ball](/wiki/LaVar_Ball "LaVar
Ball").[31][32][33]

Prior to the beginning of the 2017-18 season, the team travelled to China to
participate in the annual Pac-12 China Game. On November 6 in
[Hangzhou](/wiki/Hangzhou "Hangzhou"), during a block of free time allotted to
the players, freshmen [LiAngelo Ball](/wiki/LiAngelo_Ball "LiAngelo Ball"),
Cody Riley and Jalen Hill shoplifted sunglasses from a [Louis
Vuitton](/wiki/Louis_Vuitton "Louis Vuitton") department store. They were
placed under house arrest by local police the next day and required to hand
over their passports.[34] The controversy garnered immense attention due to
the reputation of LiAngelo as a member of the [Ball
family](/wiki/Ball_in_the_Family "Ball in the Family") and received
significant media coverage. President [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump
"Donald Trump"), who was concurrently visiting China, reportedly asked General
Secretary [Xi Jinping](/wiki/Xi_Jinping "Xi Jinping") to pardon the three men,
and they were released back to the United States shortly after, although
Ball's family questioned if the President's request was a direct reason for
the release.[35] The players were placed on suspension from basketball
activities, and were eventually suspended for the entirety of the season on
December 22nd.[36] Believing the suspension to have been unearned, LaVar Ball
preemptively withdrew LiAngelo from UCLA and had him sign with an agent,
making him ineligible for further NCAA competition.[37]

UCLA finished the regular season in a three-way tie for third (tied with Utah
and Stanford) in the Pac-12 (21-10, 11-7), and junior guard [Aaron
Holiday](/wiki/Aaron_Holiday "Aaron Holiday") was named to the First-team
[All-Pac-12](/wiki/List_of_All-Pac-12_Conference_men%27s_basketball_teams
"List of All-Pac-12 Conference men's basketball teams") and the Pac-12 All
Defensive Team, the first player to do so in the Alford era.[38]

##
Facilities[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Facilities")]

The men's basketball team played in the 2,400 seat [Men's
Gym](/wiki/Men%27s_Gym "Men's Gym") from 1932 to 1965. They also played at
other venues around Los Angeles, including the [Pan-Pacific
Auditorium](/wiki/Pan-Pacific_Auditorium "Pan-Pacific Auditorium") and [Los
Angeles Memorial Sports Arena](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Memorial_Sports_Arena "Los
Angeles Memorial Sports Arena"), when larger crowds were expected for games.

### Pauley
Pavilion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Pauley Pavilion")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Pauley_Pavilion_2013.JPG/220px-
Pauley_Pavilion_2013.JPG)](/wiki/File:Pauley_Pavilion_2013.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Pauley_Pavilion_2013.JPG "Enlarge")

[UCLA Bruins](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_team
"2012–13 UCLA Bruins men's basketball team") vs. [Oregon State
Beavers](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_Oregon_State_Beavers_men%27s_basketball_team
"2012–13 Oregon State Beavers men's basketball team"), January 2013, in the
"New Pauley Pavilion"

Following UCLA's second championship in 1964, the idea of constructing a new
arena to accommodate increased interest in the team was proposed. In 1965,
[Pauley Pavilion](/wiki/Pauley_Pavilion "Pauley Pavilion") was built on campus
and has been the home of the Bruins basketball programs since that time.
During the 2011–12 season, Pauley Pavilion underwent a complete, $136 million
renovation, both inside and out, earning it the nickname of "New Pauley." [39]
A new attendance record was set on March 2, 2013 when 13,727 fans watched the
Bruins defeating the Arizona Wildcats 74–69.

### Mo Ostin Basketball
Center[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Mo Ostin Basketball Center")]

The Mo Ostin Basketball Center will be built south of the Los Angeles Tennis
Center and close to Pauley Pavilion, the basketball team's home court to serve
as a practice facility and hub for the basketball team. On December 14, 2015,
[Russell Westbrook](/wiki/Russell_Westbrook "Russell Westbrook") donated a
"significant" sum to the construction of the Center, for which the facility's
court was named in his honor.[40] Westbrook's former teammate, [Kevin
Love](/wiki/Kevin_Love "Kevin Love"), matched his contribution on September
20, 2016, for which the strength and conditioning center was named after
him.[41]

Main article: [List of UCLA Bruins men's basketball head
coaches](/wiki/List_of_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_head_coaches "List of
UCLA Bruins men's basketball head coaches")

The team has had 12 [head coaches](/wiki/Head_coaches "Head coaches") in its
history, and they have won 11 [NCAA
Championships](/wiki/NCAA_Division_I_Men%27s_Basketball_Championship "NCAA
Division I Men's Basketball Championship"), the most of any school.[42] [John
Wooden](/wiki/John_Wooden "John Wooden") won 10 national championships between
[1964](/wiki/1963%E2%80%9364_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_team "1963–64 UCLA
Bruins men's basketball team") and
[1975](/wiki/1974%E2%80%9375_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_team "1974–75 UCLA
Bruins men's basketball team"), and [Jim Harrick](/wiki/Jim_Harrick "Jim
Harrick") won the other in
[1995](/wiki/1994%E2%80%9395_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_team "1994–95 UCLA
Bruins men's basketball team"). The _[New York Times](/wiki/New_York_Times
"New York Times")_ wrote that Wooden "made UCLA the most successful team in
college basketball."[43] After Wooden retired, the four coaches that succeeded
him resigned, and the following three—Harrick included—were fired. The average
tenure of those coaches after Wooden was four years.[44][a] Former coach [Ben
Howland](/wiki/Ben_Howland "Ben Howland"), led the Bruins to three consecutive
[Final Four](/wiki/Final_Four_\(college_basketball\) "Final Four \(college
basketball\)") appearances from
[2006](/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_team "2005–06 UCLA
Bruins men's basketball team") to
[2008](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball_team "2007–08 UCLA
Bruins men's basketball team").[45]

##
Rivals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Rivals")]

###
USC[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: USC")]

See also: [UCLA–USC rivalry](/wiki/UCLA%E2%80%93USC_rivalry "UCLA–USC
rivalry")

When [John Wooden](/wiki/John_Wooden "John Wooden") became the coach, UCLA
turned into a national basketball powerhouse. UCLA has won 11 [NCAA Division I
Men's Basketball
Tournaments](/wiki/NCAA_Division_I_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournament "NCAA
Division I Men's Basketball Tournament") and has dominated the conference,
winning two games for every one that USC won. As of the 2013–2014 season, UCLA
has won or shared the conference title 31 times, and USC has won or shared the
title 7 times.[46] There have been a number of [significant
games](/wiki/UCLA%E2%80%93USC_rivalry#Men.27s "UCLA–USC rivalry") in this
rivalry

### Notre Dame, Arizona and
California[[edit](/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Notre Dame, Arizona and California")]

See also: [Notre Dame-UCLA rivalry](/wiki/Notre_Dame-UCLA_rivalry "Notre Dame-
UCLA rivalry")

UCLA had a basketball rivalry with [Notre
Dame](/wiki/Notre_Dame_Fighting_Irish_men%27s_basketball "Notre Dame Fighting
Irish men's basketball") that started when [Digger Phelps](/wiki/Digger_Phelps
"Digger Phelps") was the Notre Dame coach and [John Wooden](/wiki/John_Wooden
"John Wooden") was the UCLA coach. UCLA and Notre Dame played a home-and-home
meeting for several seasons, which is otherwise uncommon outside conference
play. This rivalry existed from the desire of the Notre Dame athletic
department to schedule the top schools for intersectional competition. UCLA
and Notre Dame played 42 times between 1966 and 1995, and the height of the
rivalry was when Notre Dame ended UCLA's consecutive-game winning streak at 88
on January 19, 1974. UCLA also broke a 60-game Notre Dame winning streak in
South Bend. Previous UCLA head coach [Ben Howland](/wiki/Ben_Howland "Ben
Howland") scheduled Notre Dame four times: in 2004, 2005, 2008, and 2009.[47]
After UCLA's victory on February 7, 2009, UCLA leads the all-time series
28-19.[48]

See also: [Arizona-UCLA basketball rivalry](/wiki/Arizona-
UCLA_basketball_rivalry "Arizona-UCLA basketball rivalry")

Since the mid-1980s, UCLA has also had a basketball rivalry with
[Arizona](/wiki/Arizona_Wildcats_men%27s_basketball "Arizona Wildcats men's
basketball") under coach [Lute Olson](/wiki/Lute_Olson "Lute Olson"), as the
two schools competed for the Pac-10 Championship every year. Since 1985 the
two teams have combined to win 21 out of the 29 conference titles. The UCLA-
Arizona basketball rivalry still is seen as the match up of the two premier
teams in the conference. Also, the performance of the two schools influences
the national opinion of the conference.[49]

[Andy Hill](/wiki/Andy_Hill_\(basketball\) "Andy Hill \(basketball\)"), [Terry
Schofield](/wiki/Terry_Schofield "Terry Schofield"), [Bill
Sweek](/wiki/Bill_Sweek "Bill Sweek"), and [Larry
Hollyfield](/wiki/Larry_Hollyfield "Larry Hollyfield").[b][58][59]

UCLA became the first school to have a top winner in both basketball and
football in the same year with [Gary Beban](/wiki/Gary_Beban "Gary Beban")
winning the Heisman Trophy and [Lew Alcindor](/wiki/Lew_Alcindor "Lew
Alcindor") (now [Kareem Abdul-Jabbar](/wiki/Kareem_Abdul-Jabbar "Kareem Abdul-
Jabbar")) winning the [U.S. Basketball Writers
Association](/wiki/Oscar_Robertson_Trophy "Oscar Robertson Trophy") player of
the year award in 1968.

UCLA has produced the most [NBA Most Valuable Player
Award](/wiki/NBA_Most_Valuable_Player_Award "NBA Most Valuable Player Award")
winners, six of them by Abdul-Jabbar, one to Walton, who was Abdul-Jabbar's
successor, and one to Russell Westbrook.[50] As of the [2017–18 NBA
season](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_NBA_season "2017–18 NBA
season")[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball&action=edit),
91 former [UCLA players have played in the
NBA](/wiki/List_of_UCLA_Bruins_in_the_NBA "List of UCLA Bruins in the
NBA").[60][61][c][d]

At the [2015 NBA All-Star Game](/wiki/2015_NBA_All-Star_Game "2015 NBA All-
Star Game") and the [2016 NBA All-Star Game](/wiki/2016_NBA_All-Star_Game
"2016 NBA All-Star Game"), former Bruins [Russell
Westbrook](/wiki/Russell_Westbrook "Russell Westbrook") of the [Oklahoma City
Thunder](/wiki/Oklahoma_City_Thunder "Oklahoma City Thunder") was the MVP and
[Zach LaVine](/wiki/Zach_LaVine "Zach LaVine") of the [Minnesota
Timberwolves](/wiki/Minnesota_Timberwolves "Minnesota Timberwolves") was the
winner of the [Slam Dunk Contest](/wiki/Slam_Dunk_Contest "Slam Dunk
Contest"). [Lonzo Ball](/wiki/Lonzo_Ball "Lonzo Ball") second pick in the 2017
NBA draft is the first player ever with his own signature shoe (ZO2) entering
the NBA draft, he’s signed with [Big Baller Brand](/wiki/Big_Baller_Brand "Big
Baller Brand").
